title: ‘He’s dangerous’: Hackett family’s plea for help
text:
NICK TABAKOFF & GREG STOLZ The Daily Telegraph Share Share on Twitter 
THE family of one of Australia’s greatest-ever swimmers, Grant Hackett, have reached their wit’s end — with his brother dubbing the triple Olympic gold medallist as “dangerous” in the wake of his Gold Coast arrest. 
In remarkable comments to the media, Craig Hackett yesterday said: “We’ve reached the end of the road. He had the world at his feet … such a role model to so many kids … and now no one knows what’s going to happen. It doesn’t look encouraging. Former Australian Olympic swimmer Grant Hackett leaving Southport Court yesterday. Picture: NIGEL HALLETT Source: News Corp Australia 
“It’s coming to the point now where he is dangerous. He’s a danger to himself, he’s a danger to the community, and poor Mum and Dad have tried to look after him so much. I’m concerned for their welfare.” 
The Daily Telegraph can also reveal a family member ­recently sought out a court order against Hackett that expires in January 2019, requiring him to be of “good behaviour” until then. 
Hackett’s father Neville said yesterday Hackett “had a mental breakdown” after drinking heavily. Hackett was arrested yesterday after police were called to his family home shortly before midday following reports he flew into a violent rage in the latest in a spate of meltdowns. Eight officers had to be called to Hackett’s home. Picture: Jerad Williams Source: News Corp Australia 
There were varying reports about the exact nature of that disturbance, with some suggesting that Hackett had stabbed a knife into a chopping block. Eight police officers ­arrived at the Hacketts’ home at Mermaid Waters and took him into custody in handcuffs. 
He was kept in Southport watch-house for several hours before being released without charge, and was later believed to have been taken to a Gold Coast private hospital. 
News of Hackett’s arrest has shaken the Australian sporting community right up to its top echelons. Hackett handcuffed in the back of a police car after allegedly flying into a fit of uncontrollable rage” that forced his parents to call the police. Picture: Channel 7 Source: Channel 7 
Australian Olympic Committee president John Coates told The Daily Telegraph last night: “This is just a big shock and surprise. I am very worried for him and his family. 
“He is one of ours. He’s an Olympian, and one of our greatest Olympians. We’ll give him whatever support we can.” 
The seriousness of the incident was not played down by his clearly emotional brother yesterday. 
“The Grant Hackett that Australia fell in love with … this is not Grant Hackett,” Craig said. “This is a completely different person. I don’t know this person, my mum and dad don’t know this person. Craig Hackett, brother of Grant Hackett, says the fallen champion is a danger to himself and the community. Source: AAP 
“He’s there in person — but he’s not there in mind, soul or spirit.” 
Probed on the incident, Hackett’s father said: “He just became abusive and aggressive. When I say aggressive, (I mean) aggressive verbally, and didn’t make any sense. And it was obvious that something was wrong, and I phoned the police.” Nev Hackett 'We will do anything to help him' 1:21 
Grant Hackett's father Nev talks to reporters following the Olympian's arrest at their Gold Coast family home. Courtesy: AAP February 15th 2017 16 hours ago /video/video.news.com.au/News/ 
Mr Hackett senior said his son was “big and powerful when he’s not happy”, and that he was hard to persuade to receive the treatment he clearly needed in the state he was in yesterday. 
“We decided he needed some treatment,” he said. “But there was no way he was going to go and get treatment … so we called the police. Hackett was kept at a Gold Coast watch-house for several hours before being released without charge. Picture: NIGEL HALLETT Source: News Corp Australia 
“The only way the police can do anything under the law of the land is to arrest him for domestic violence.” 
Hackett was later released without charge. 
Yesterday’s incident is the latest in a spate of meltdowns involving the increasingly ­erratic Olympian. Hackett ­entered rehab in 2012 for ­addiction to the powerful prescription drug Stilnox, and underwent treatment again in 2014 after he was found wandering semi-naked around Melbourne’s Crown Casino claiming to have lost his son. Grant Hackett's highs and lows Source: The Daily Telegraph 
It followed an ugly divorce from singer Candice Alley and the alleged trashing of their Melbourne apartment. Last April he was involved in a mid-air scandal when he allegedly “forcefully” tweaked the nipple of a fellow passenger on board a Virgin flight. 
After that incident, Hackett — who has worked as a senior banker with Westpac and as a Channel 9 commentator after retiring from swimming — said “binge drinking is an issue that I need to address and something I will address”.
